@graph.involvedParties: Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc., NASD
@graph.reasoning: The Court found that the securities law precluded antitrust liability even in respect to a practice that both antitrust law and securities law might forbid.
@graph.citation: Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc., O. T. 1974, No. 74–304

@graph.reasoning: The Court found that antitrust law (e.g., forbidding resale price maintenance) and securities law (e.g., permitting resale price maintenance) were in conflict.
The Court found that the securities law, by implication, precluded all parts of the antitrust claim.
@graph.citation: Herman & MacLean v. Huddleston, 459 U. S. 375, 383

@graph.@id: Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC v. Billing
@graph.reasoning: The Court rejected the argument that the saving clauses were so broad as to preserve all antitrust actions.
@graph.citation: Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC v. Billing, 551 U. S. 264 (2007)
